question: Your kid brother got married last Sunday, eh, Marty?
answer: That's right, Missus Fusari. It was a very nice affair.

question: That's the big tall one, the fellow with the moustache.
answer: No, that's my other brother, Freddie. My other brother Freddie, he's been married four years already. He lives down on Webb Avenue. The one who got married Sunday, that was my little brother, Nickie.

question: I thought he was a big tall fat fellow. Didn't I meet him here one time? Big tall, fat fellow, he tried to sell me life insurance?
answer: No, that's my sister Margaret's husband, Frank. My sister Margaret, she's married to the insurance salesman, and my sister Rose, she married a contractor. They moved to Detroit last year. And my other sister Frances, she got married about two and a half years ago in Saint John's Church on Kingsbridge Avenue. Oh, that was a big affair. Well, let's see now, that'll be about a dollar- seventy-nine. How's that with you?

question: Well...
answer: You're next right now, Missus Canduso.

question: When you gonna get married, Marty? You should be ashamed of yourself. All your brothers and sisters, they all younger than you, they married and they got children. I just saw your mother inna fruit shop, and she says to me, "Hey, you know a nice girl for my boy Marty?" Watsa matter with you? That's no way. Now you get married.
answer: Missus Fusari, Missus Canduso over there, she's inna big hurry, and...

question: My son Frank, he was married when he was nineteen years old. Watsa matter with you?
answer: That's swell, Missus Fusari.

question: You should be ashamed of yourself.
answer: Yeah, it was a very nice affair. What happened? Any homers? Angie come in yet?

question: Yeah, it was a very nice affair. What happened? Any homers? Angie come in yet?
answer: So these two girls come over to the bar...

question: Hey, Ang'...
answer: ...and they sit down right next to me...

question: You want a beer, Ang'?
answer: I look over at this one nexta me, not bad, about thirty-five -- Hiya, Marty...

question: Hiya, Ralph...
answer: ...I been talking about two nurses Leo and me picked up in a bar on Seventy-First Street.

question: Hey, Lou, gimme two bottles-a beer...
answer: So, Marty, lemme tell you about these nurses, Marty...

question: Waddaya read there, Joe?
answer: Turns out these two girls are nurses in some hospital on a Hundred and Fourth Street...

question: So waddaya feel like doing tonight?
answer: I don't know, Ang'. Wadda you feel like doing?

question: Well, we oughta do something. It's Saturday night. I don't wanna go bowling like last Saturday. How about calling up that big girl we picked up inna movies about a month ago in the RKO Chester?
answer: Which one was that?

question: That big girl that was sitting in front of us with the skinny friend.
answer: Oh, yeah.

question: We took them home alla way out in Brooklyn. Her name was Mary Feeney. What do you say? You think I oughta give her a ring? I'll take the skinny one.
answer: She probably got a date by now, Angie.

question: Well, let's call her up. What can we lose?
answer: I didn't like her, Angie. I don't feel like calling her up.

question: Well, what do you feel like doing tonight?
answer: I don't know. What do you feel like doing?

question: Well, we're back to that, huh? I say to you, "What do you feel like doing tonight?" And you say to me, "I don't know, what do you feel like doing?" And then we wind up sitting around your house with a coupla cansa beer, watching Sid Caesar on television. Well, I tell you what I feel like doing. I feel like calling up this Mary Feeney. She likes you.
answer: What makes you say that?

question: I could see she likes you.
answer: Yeah, sure.

question: I'll call her up.
answer: You call her up for yourself, Angie. I don't feel like calling her up.

question: How about going downa Seventy-Second Street, see what we can find? Ralph says you have to beat them off with clubs. Boy, you're getting to be a real drag, you know that?
answer: Angie, I'm thirty-four years old. I been looking for a girl every Saturday night of my life. I'm tired of looking. Everybody's always telling me to get married. Get married. Get married. Don't you think I wanna get married? I wanna get married. They drive me crazy. Now, I don't wanna wreck your Saturday night for you, Angie. You wanna go somewhere, you go ahead. I don't wanna go.

question: My old lady, every word outta her mouth, when you gonna get married?
answer: My mother, boy, she drives me crazy.

question: So what do you feel like doing tonight?
answer: I don't know. What do you feel like doing?

question: Okay, you come on home, okay. He coming home right now.
answer: So what happened, Aunt Theresa, about the milk bottle was my mother-in- law, she comes inna kitchen, Aunt Theresa, and she begins poking her head over my shoulder here and poking her head over my shoulder there, so then she begins telling me how I waste money and how I can't cook, and how I'm raising my baby all wrong, so she got me so nervous, I spilled some milk I was making for the baby...

question: She was here, you know, Wednesday, and I said, "Catherine, my sister..."
answer: So she say, "You're spilling the milk." So she kept talking about these coupla drops of milk I spilled, so she got me so mad, so I said, "Mama, you wanna see me really spill some milk?" So I took the bottle, and I threw it against the door. I didn't throw it at her. That's just something she made up. She goes around telling everybody I threw the bottla milk at her. I didn't throw it anywheres near her. Well, I was sorry right away, you know, but she ran outta the house.

question: We want you to do a very big favor for us, Aunt Theresa.
answer: Sure.

question: Aunt Theresa, you got this big house here. I mean, you got this big house just for you and Marty. And I thought maybe Tommy's mother could come here and live with you and Marty.
answer: Well...

question: Because I called up Tommy's brother Joe, and I said, "Joe, she's driving me crazy. Why don't you take her for a couple of years?" And he said, "Oh no!" I know I sound like a terrible woman...
answer: No, Virginia, I know how you feel.

question: All right, Ginnie, don't get so excited.
answer: She's right. She's right. Young husband and wife, they should have their own home. And my sister Catherine, she's my sister, but I gotta admit, she's an old goat. And plenty-a times in my life, I feel like throwing the milk bottle at her myself. And I tell you now, as far as I'm concerned, if Catherine wantsa come live here with me and Marty, it's all right with me.

question: That's very nice-a you, Aunt Theresa.
answer: We gotta ask Marty, of course.

question: Sure.
answer: You just sit here, I gotta turn the fire on under the cooking.

question: How's Marty been lately, Aunt Theresa?
answer: Oh, he's fine. You know a nice girl he can marry?

question: Oh, he'll get married, don't worry, Aunt Theresa.
answer: Well, I don't know. He sits arounna house alla time. You know a place he can go where he can find a bride?

question: Well, there's the Stardust Ballroom. That's a kind of a big dance hall. Every Saturday night, it's just loaded with girls. It's a nice place to go. You pay seventy-seven cents. It used to be seventy-seven cents. It must be about a buck and half now. And you go in and you ask some girl to dance. That's how I met Virginia. Nice, respectable place to meet girls. You tell Marty, Aunt Theresa, you tell him, "Go to the Stardust Ballroom. It's loaded with tomatoes."
answer: The Stardust Ballroom. It's loaded with tomatoes.

question: He's here.
answer: Hello, Ma.

question: Marty, Thomas and Virginia are here. They had another fight with your Aunt Catherine. So they ask me, would it be all right if Catherine come to live with us. So I said, all right with me, but we have to ask you. Marty, she's a lonely old lady. Nobody wants her. Everybody's throwing her outta their house...
answer: Sure, Ma, it's okay with me.

question: Siddown, Thomas, siddown.
answer: I'm sorry we gotta rush like this...

question: That's all right, that's all right...
answer: On accounta...

question: I'll see you at mass tomorrow. We'll sit down and we'll discuss the whole thing.
answer: All right, I'll see you, Thomas, because he wants an answer by Monday.

question: Sure. Thanks a lot about my mother. We'll work out some arrangement, because naturally I want to pay...
answer: Don't worry about it.

question: Goodby, Virginia! See you soon! Hello, is this Mary Feeney?... Could I speak to Miss Mary Feeney?... Just tell her an old friend... ...Oh, hello there, is this Mary Feeney? Hello there, this is Marty Pilletti. I wonder if you recall me... Well, I'm kind of a stocky guy. The last time we met was in a movie, the RKO Chester. You was with another girl, and I was with a friend of mine named Angie. This was about a month ago... The RKO Chester in Westchester Square. You was sitting in front of us, and we was annoying you, and you got mad, and... I'm the fellow who works in a butcher shop... Come on, you know who I am!... That's right, we went to Howard Johnson's and we had hamburgers. You hadda milkshake... Yeah, that's right. I'm the stocky one, the heavy-set feller... Well, I'm glad you recall me, because I hadda swell time that night, and I was just wondering how everything was with you. How's everything?... That's swell... Yeah, well, I'll tell you why I called...I was figuring on taking in a movie tonight, and I was wondering if you and your friend would care to see a movie tonight with me and my friend... Yeah, tonight. I know it's pretty late to call for a date, but I didn't know myself, till... Yeah, I know, well how about... Yeah, I know, well maybe next Saturday night. You free next Saturday night?... Well, how about the Saturday after that?... Yeah, I know... Yeah... Yeah... Oh, I understand, I mean...
answer: So what are you gonna do tonight, Marty?

question: I don't know, Ma. I'm all knocked out. I may just hang arounna house.
answer: Why don't you go to the Stardust Ballroom?

question: What?
answer: I say, why don't you go to the Stardust Ballroom? It's loaded with tomatoes.

question: It's loaded with what?
answer: Tomatoes.

question: Ha! Who told you about the Stardust Ballroom?
answer: Thomas. He told me it was a very nice place.

question: Oh, Thomas. Ma, it's just a big dance hall, and that's all it is. I been there a hundred times. Loaded with tomatoes. Boy, you're funny, Ma.
answer: Marty, I don't want you hang arounna house tonight. I want you to go take a shave and go out and dance.

question: Ma, when are you gonna give up? You gotta bachelor on your hands. I ain't never gonna get married.
answer: You gonna get married.

question: Sooner or later, there comes a point in a man's life when he gotta face some facts, and one fact I gotta face is that whatever it is that women like, I ain't got it. I chased enough girls in my life. I went to enough dances. I got hurt enough. I don't wanna get hurt no more. I just called a girl just now, and I got a real brush-off, boy. I figured I was past the point of being hurt, but that hurt. Some stupid woman who I didn't even wanna call up. She gave me the brush. I don't wanna go to the Stardust Ballroom because all that ever happened to me there was girls made me feel like I was a bug. I got feelings, you know. I had enough pain. No, thank you.
answer: Marty...

question: Ma, I'm gonna stay home and watch Jackie Gleason.
answer: You gonna die without a son.

question: So I'll die without a son.
answer: Put on your blue suit...

question: Blue suit, gray suit, I'm still a fat man. A fat ugly man.
answer: You not ugly.

question: I'm ugly... I'm ugly! I'm UGLY!
answer: Marty...

question: I told you she wasn't especially attractive, but that she had a good deal of charm, and she's really a real nice girl...
answer: She's all right, Andy. It's just that I get one Saturday night off every three weeks, and I was expecting something better, that's all.

question: I told you she wasn't attractive...
answer: You told me that she was a little tall, but that she wasn't bad looking at all.

question: Millie's been after me to fix her up with a date, so I...
answer: All right, I'm having a fair time. It's just that I get one Saturday night off in three weeks, and I wanted to wind up with something tonight. Hey! I came up to dance, wadda you think? You here with somebody? Where you going now? I'll see you around. That's a girl used to know.

question: Boy, it's packed in here.
answer: I wouldn't think so. I teach out in Brooklyn.

question: You been up here before, Clara?
answer: Yeah, twice.

question: Hey, Herbie... Hey, Herbie...
answer: What?

question: You wanna have a drink before we start dancing?
answer: Listen. You people go grab a table. I'll be back inna minute. I'll be right back.

question: Not a bad crowd tonight, you know?
answer: There was one nice-looking one there inna black dress and beads, but she's dancing now.

question: There's a nice-looking little short one for you right now.
answer: Where?

question: Down there. That little one there.
answer: Yeah, she looks all right from here.

question: Well, waddaya say, you wanna ask them? I'll take the one inna green dress.
answer: I think this number is a little fast. Wait a minute. It's all right, I think. They still there?

question: Waddaya say, you wanna dance?
answer: Excuse me, would you care for this dance? Sure.

question: Excuse me, would you care for this dance? Sure.
answer: You here stag or with a girl?

question: You say something?
answer: Yeah. I was just asking you if you was here stag or with a girl.

question: I'm stag.
answer: Well, I'll tell you. I got stuck on a blind date with a dog, and I just met an old girl I used to know, and I was wondering how I'm gonna get rid of the girl I'm with. Somebody to take her home, you know what I mean? I'd be glad to pay you five bucks if you take her home for me.

question: What?
answer: I'll take you over, and I'll introduce you as an old army buddy of mine, and then I'll cut out. Because I got this other girl waiting for me out by the hatcheck, and I'll pay you five bucks.

question: Are you kidding?
answer: No, I'm not kidding.

question: You can't just walk off onna girl like that.
answer: ...in that case, as long as she's going home alone, give me the five bucks back...

question: I think it be a better idea if you and Thomas go out, because otherwise she's gonna start a fight with you, and everybody's gonna be yelling.
answer: Hello, Aunt Theresa.

question: Hello, Thomas.
answer: I just this minute got the baby to sleep. Aunt Theresa, we figure the best way to ask her is you say that you're very lonely, see? And wouldn't she come and keep you company, because that way, you see...

question: Don't worry. I'm gonna take care-a the whole thing. It's me, Catherine! How you feel?
answer: Hey! What are you doing here?

question: I came to see you. How you feel?
answer: I gotta pain in my left side, and my leg throbs like a drum.

question: I been getting a pain in my shoulder.
answer: I gotta pains in my shoulder too. I have a pain in my hip, and my right arm aches so much I can't sleep. It's a curse to be old. How you feel?

question: I feel fine.
answer: That's nice.

question: Well, how's everything with you? My son Marty's fine. Everybody's fine... We gotta postcard from my son Nickie and his bride. They're inna big hotel in Florida on their honeymoon. Everything is very nice.
answer: That's nice. I gotta letter from my husband's cousin in Abruzzi. His mother died.

question: Oh.
answer: Do you remember Emilio DiGiorgio, owned the tavern in Abruzzi?

question: I don't think I remember him.
answer: Well, he died. You know who else died?

question: Who?
answer: You know the old man upstairs in this house. Old Irishman, always drunk. He got pleurisy. He was inna hospital two weeks. He died yesterday.

question: I wake up this morning, I hear the baby crying. So I wake up. I come in their room. That girl is shaking her hand atta baby. I said, "You brute! Don't you strike that baby! That's my son's baby!"
answer: It's her baby too, you know.

question: That's my son Thomas's baby.
answer: Well, it ain't your baby.

question: Did I tell you she threw the bottle- a milk at me?
answer: You told me.

question: She's a witch, that one. I tell you what happen yesterday?
answer: What happen?

question: She gave me the evil eye.
answer: Ufa!

question: I keep one eye open when I sleep, because she's gonna come in, stab me in my bed.
answer: Catherine, I want you come live in my house with Marty and me.

question: Ah?
answer: You son Thomas and Virginia, they come to my house this afternoon...

question: Who?
answer: Your son Thomas and his wife Virginia...

question: When was this?
answer: This afternoon, about four, five o'clock.

question: What they say?
answer: You know what they say. They say things are no good in this house. Catherine, your son is married. Leave him in peace. He wantsa be alone with his wife. They don't want no old lady sitting inna balcony. Now I tell you what I think. I want you come live with me in my house with Marty and me. In my house, you have your own room. You don't have to sleep onna couch inna living room like here. We will cook inna kitchen and talk like when we were girls. You are dear to me, and you are dear to Marty. We are pleased for you to come.

question: My son Thomas came to see you this afternoon, and he said to you he wants to cast his mother from his house?
answer: Catherine, don't make an opera outta this. The three-a you anna baby live in three skinny rooms. You are an old goat, and she has an Italian temper. She is a good girl, but you drive her crazy. Catherine, you are no fool. You know this is no good, an old woman living with a husband and wife. Two women inna same kitchen, anna house burns down.

question: So I am an old garbage bag, put inna street.
answer: Oh, Catherine, please! Don't make a tragedy. You come to my house where you know you be happier yourself.

question: It pains that they should do this.
answer: I know it pains.

question: These are the worst years, I tell you.
answer: Catherine, you are very dear to me. We have cried many times together. When my husband died, I would have gone insane if it were not for you. I ask you to come to my house, because I can make you happy. Please come to my house.

question: These are the worst years. I tell you. It's gonna happen to you. I'm afraida look inna mirror. I'm afraid I'm gonna see an old lady with white hair, like the old ladies inna park, little bundles inna black shawl, waiting for the coffin. I'm fifty- six years old. What am I to do with myself? I have strength in my hands. I wanna cook. I wanna clean. I wanna make dinner for my children. Am I an old dog to lie in fronta the fire til my eyes close? These are the terrible years, Theresa! Terrible years!
answer: Catherine, my sister...

question: You come up here often?
answer: I was up here twice before. Once with a friend of mine and once I came up alone. The last time... do you see that girl in the gray dress sitting over there?

question: Yeah.
answer: Well, the last time I was up here, that's where I sat. I sat there for an hour and a half, without moving a muscle. Now and then, some fellow would sort of walk up to me and then change his mind. I'll never forget just sitting there for an hour and a half with my hands in my lap. Then I began to cry, and I had to get up and go home.

question: I cry a lot too. I'm a big cryer.
answer: This is something recent with me, this bursting into tears at the least thing.

question: Oh, I cry all the time, any little thing. My brothers, my brother-in- laws, they're always telling me what a goodhearted guy I am. Well, you don't get goodhearted by accident. You get kicked around long enough, you get to be a real professor of pain. I know exactly how you feel. And I also want you to know I'm having a very good time with you now and really enjoying myself. So you see, you're not such a dog as you think you are.
answer: I'm having a very good time, too.

question: So there you are. So I guess I'm not such a dog as I think I am.
answer: You're a very nice guy, and I don't know why some girl hasn't grabbed you off long ago.

question: I don't know either. I think I'm a very nice guy. I also think I'm a pretty smart guy in my own way. Now I figure, two people get married, and they gonna live together forty, fifty years. So it's just gotta be more than whether they're good looking or not. You tell me you think you're not very good-looking. My father was a really ugly man, but my mother adored him. She told me that she used to get so miserable sometimes, like everybody, you know? And she says my father always tried to understand. I used to see them sometimes when I was a kid, sitting in the living room, talking and talking, and I used to adore my old man, because he was so kind. That's one of the most beautiful things I have in my life, the way my father and mother were. And my father was a real ugly man. So it doesn't matter if you look like a gorilla. So you see, dogs like us, we ain't such dogs as we think we are.
answer: I'm twenty-nine years old. How old are you?

question: I'm thirty-four. ...you teach chemistry? That's funny. Where? What school?
answer: Benjamin Franklin High School.

question: Benjamin Franklin, where's that? Brooklyn? I went to Theodore Roosevelt right up here on Fordham Road. It's right arounna corner from my house. I have a cousin who's a teacher. He teaches Latin. He lives in Chicago. He was studying to be a Jesuit, but he gave it up after his first vows. I was pretty good in high school. I sound like a jerk now, but I was pretty good. I graduated with an eighty-two average. That ain't bad. I was accepted at City College. I filled out the application and everything, but my old man died, so I hadda go to work. My best class was German. That was my first language. Der, die, das -- des, der, des. There you are, I still remember... You know what I was good at in high school? I was good in Math. You know how long ago I graduated high school? June, nineteen-thirty-seven. Holy cow! June, nineteen-thirty-seven! What is that? Fifteen, seventeen years ago! Holy cow! Seventeen years ago! Is that right? Seventeen, that's right. Where did it all go? I'm getting old. I'm gonna be thirty- five November eighth. Thirty-five. Wow. Time goes on, boy. Nineteen-thirty-seven... that's right. My old man died December, nineteen- thirty-seven. Two o'clock in the morning he died. The doorbell rings, and I knew something was wrong right away. Because my room is onna ground floor inna front, you see, and I got outta bed, and I answered the door... There was Mr. Stern. He had a house down about a block from us. He moved out though. My old man, he used to play cards with him and some other old guys. He's a Jewish feller. So he said, "Is your mother home?" So I knew right away there was something wrong. I was only eighteen, exactly eighteen years old, just the month before. So I said, "Is something wrong, Mr. Stern?" I was in my pajamas, you know? So he said, "Marty, your father died." My father died right inna middle of playing cards, right at the table. He had a heart attack. He had low blood pressure, my old man. He used to faint a lot. Boy, am I talking, I never talked so much in my life. Usually, everybody comes to me and tells me all their troubles. Well, I'm gonna shut up now, and I'm gonna let you get a word in... Seventeen years ago. What I been doing with myself all that time?... Well, I'm talking again. I must be driving you crazy. Mosta the time I'm with a girl, I can't find a word to say. Well, I'm gonna shut up now. Because I'm not like this usually. Usually, I... well, here I go again. I can't shut my mouth... I'm on a jag, for Pete's sake. You'd think I was loaded... I can't stop talking! Isn't this stupid?! You gotta real nice face, you know? It's really a nice face.
answer: Thank you.

question: ...When I got outta the army, Clara, I was lost. I didn't know what I wanted to do. I was twenny-five years old, what was I gonna do, go back to my old job, forty cents an hour. I thought maybe I go to college under the G.I. Biller Rights, you know? But I wouldn't graduate till I was twenny-eight, twenny-nine years old, even if I made it in three years. And my brother Freddie wanted to get married, and I had three unmarried sisters -- in an Italian home, that's a terrible thing. And my kid brother Nickie, he's a one got married last week. So I just went to pieces. I used to walk inna streets till three, four o'clock inna mornings. My mother used to be so worried about me. My uncle Mario come over one time. He offered me a job driving his hack onna night shift. He got his own cab, you know. And God forgive me for what I'm gonna say now, but I used to thinka doing away with myself. I used to stand sometimes in the subway, and God forgive me what I'm going to say, I used to feel the tracks sucking me down under the wheels.
answer: Yes, I know.

question: I'm a Catholic, you know, and even to think about suicide is a terrible sin.
answer: Yes, I know.

question: So then Mr. Gazzara -- he was a frienda my father -- he offered me this job in his butcher shop, and everybody pleaded with me to take it. So that's what happened. I didn't wanna be a butcher.
answer: There's nothing wrong with being a butcher.

question: Well, I wouldn't call it an elegant profession. It's in a lower social scale. People look down on butchers.
answer: I don't.

question: Well, the point is Mr. Gazzara wantsa sell his shop now, because he and his wife are lonely, and they wanna move out to California in Los Angeles and live near their married daughter. Because she's always writing them to come out there. So it's a nice little shop. I handle his books for him, so I know he has a thirty-five percent markup which is not unreasonable, and he takes home net maybe a hundred, hundred and fifty bucks a week. The point is, of course, you gotta worry about the supermarkets. There's two inna neighborhood now, and there's an A&P coming in, at least that's the rumor. Of course, mosta his trade is strictly Italian, but the younger Italian girls, they get married, and they don't stick to the old Italian dishes so much. I mean, you gotta take that into account too.
answer: It's my feeling that you really want to buy this shop, Marty.

question: That's true. I do. But I'm gonna have to take outta loan inna bank eight thousand dollars. That's a big note to carry, because I have to give Mr. Gazzara a mortgage, and what I have to weigh is
answer: Marty, I know you for three hours, but I know you're a good butcher. You're an intelligent, sensitive, decent man. I have a feeling about you like sometimes a kid comes in to see me for one reason or another. And some of these kids, Marty, in my classes, they have so much warmth in them, so much capacity. And that's the feeling I get about you. If you were one of my students, I would say, "Go ahead and buy the butcher shop. You're a good butcher."

question: Well, there's a lotta things I could do with this shop. I could organize my own supermarket. Get a buncha neighborhood merchants together. That's what a lotta them are doing. Wadda you think?
answer: I think anything you want to do, you'll do well.

question: I'm Catholic. Are you Catholic?
answer: Yes, I am.

question: I only got about three bucks on me now, but I just live about eight blocks from here on the other side of Webster Avenue. Why don't we walk back to my house? I'll run in, pick up some dough, and let's step out somewhere.
answer: I really should get home...

question: It's only a quarter of twelve. The clock's right over there.
answer: I really should get home, I told my father... Well, I suppose a little while longer. I wonder if there's any place around here I could put some makeup on...

question: Well, last week Tuesday, she gave birth to the baby in Saint Elizabeth's hospital... a big healthy boy of nine pounds...
answer: Oh, that's nice. So the doctor was wrong, wasn't he?

question: Oh, no! She died right in the hospital...
answer: Oh, that's a sad story. And her husband is that little fellow, works in Peter Reeves.

question: That's the one.
answer: Oh, that's a sad story.

question: ...It's really a fine opportunity for me. But I'm not sure I want to be a department head. It's mostly executive and administrative work. Well, anyway, I told you about my father, and he depends on me a great deal, and...
answer: Why don't you just move out to Portchester?

question: Well, that's what I was saying. My father is getting old. And we're very close. He's a wonderful man, really...
answer: I think you're kidding yourself, Clara. I used to think about moving out, you know? And that's what I used to say. "My mother needs me." But when you really get down to it, that ain't it at all. Actually, you need your father. You know what I mean? You're living at home, and you got your father and mother there, and you can go on like that -- being a little girl all your life.

question: I'm afraid of being lonely.
answer: Oh, you won't be so lonely. You'll make friends right away.

question: Actually, I don't make friends easily.
answer: What're you talking about? You're a real likeable person. You'll make friends out there in Portchester one, two, three. You'll have people visiting you alla time. I'll come visit you. I'll borrow my brother Freddie's car, or you can call me up when you feel blue, or I'll call you up. And it's gonna be nice. Don't be so afraid.

question: Hey, Marty, come here a minute. Hey, Marty, we got an odd squirrel here, you interested?
answer: Waddaya mean, Ralph?

question: Hey, Louise, I want you to meet Marty Pilletti. Marty, that's Louise Kelly, inna back seat there.
answer: Hiya.

question: Listen, Marty, these three squirrels are nurses. We're all going over Leo's house later because there's nobody there. These are the squirrels I told you about. Money inna bank, man. Wanna get inna car? She's a pretty nice-looking doll.
answer: I'm with a girl, Ralph.

question: Get ridda her. This is money inna bank.
answer: I can't do that, Ralph, because somebody already brushed her off once tonight.

question: This is a good deal here, Marty.
answer: I can't do it, Ralph. Thanks anyway. Very nice to have met you all.

question: I can't do it, Ralph. Thanks anyway. Very nice to have met you all.
answer: Hey, Ralph, we might as well get going.

question: I'll see you, Leo.
answer: I'll see you, Marty.

question: Wait a minute. Lemme find the light. I guess my mother ain't home yet. I figure my cousin Thomas and Virginia musta gone to the movies, so they won't get back till one o'clock at least. This is the kitchen.
answer: Yes, I know.

question: Come on inna dining room. Siddown, take off your coat. You want something to eat? We gotta whole half-chicken in the icebox.
answer: No, thank you. I don't think I should stay very long.

question: Sure. Just take off your coat a minute. So I was telling you, my kid brother Nickie got married last Sunday. That was a very nice affair. And they had this statue of some woman, and they had whiskey spouting outta her mouth. I never saw anything so grand in my life. And watta meal. I'm a butcher, so I know a good hunka steak when I see one. That was choice filet, right off the toppa the chuck. A buck eighty a pound. Of course, if you wanna cheaper cut, get rib steak. That gotta lotta waste on it, but it comes to about a buck and a quarter a pound, if it's trimmed. Listen, Clara, make yourself comfortable. You're all tense.
answer: Oh, I'm fine.

question: You want me to take you home, I'll take you home.
answer: Maybe that would be a good idea. No, Marty, please...

question: I like you. I like you. I been telling you all night, I like you...
answer: Marty...

question: I just wanna kiss, that's all.
answer: No...

question: Please...
answer: No...

question: Please...
answer: Marty...

question: All right! I'll take you home! All right! All I wanted was a lousy kiss! What do you think, I was gonna try something serious with my mother coming home any minute!? What am I, a leper or something?!
answer: I just didn't feel like it, that's all.

question: I'm old enough to know better. Comes New Year's Eve, everybody starts arranging parties, I'm the guy they gotta dig up a date for. Let me getta packa cigarettes, and I'll take you home.
answer: I'd like to see you again. Very much. The reason I didn't let you kiss me was because I just didn't know how to handle the situation. You're the kindest man I ever met. The reason I tell you this is because I want to see you again very much. I know that when you take me home, I'm going to just lie on my bed and think about you. I want very much to see you again.

question: Waddaya doing tomorrow night?
answer: Nothing.

question: I'll call you up tomorrow morning. Maybe, we'll go see a movie.
answer: I'd like that very much.

question: The reason I can't be definite about it now is my Aunt Catherine is probably coming over tomorrow, and I may have to help out.
answer: I'll wait for your call.

question: We better get started to your house, because the buses only run about one an hour now.
answer: All right.

question: I'll just get a packa cigarettes. Waddaya doing New Year's Eve?
answer: Nothing.

question: Well, siddown a minute. I just come inna house. I'll take off my coat. Siddown a minute.
answer: How'd you come home, Ma? Thomas give you a ride?

question: Oh, it's a sad business. My sister, Catherine, she don't get along with her daughter-in-law, so she's gonna come live with us.
answer: Oh, she's coming, eh, Ma?

question: Oh, sure. Siddown, siddown. Marty, tell her siddown.
answer: Might as well siddown a minute, Clara.

question: Did you offer the young lady some fruit?
answer: I offered her, Ma, she don't want nothing.

question: No, thank you, really, Mrs. Pilletti.
answer: It's a very sad business, I tell you. A woman, fifty-six years old, all her life, she had her own home. Now she's just an old lady, sleeping on her daughter-in-law's couch. It's a curse to be a mother, I tell you. Your children grow up and then what is left for you to do? What is a mother's life but her children? It is a very cruel thing when your son has no place for you in his home.

question: Couldn't she find some sort of hobby to fill out her time?
answer: Hobby! What can she do? She cooks and she cleans. You gotta have a house to clean. You gotta have children to cook for. These are the terrible years for a woman, the terrible years.

question: You mustn't feel too harshly against her daughter-in-law. She also wants to have a house to clean and a family to cook for.
answer: You don't think my sister Catherine should live in her daughter-in-law's house?

question: Well, I don't know the people, of course, but as a rule, I don't think a mother-in-law should live with a young couple.
answer: Where do you think a mother-in-law should go?

question: I don't think a mother should depend so much upon her children for her rewards in life.
answer: Well, maybe that's what they teach you in New York University. In real life, it don't work out that way. You wait till you are a mother.

question: Waddaya gonna do now?
answer: I'm gonna take Clara home. It's close to one.

question: You want me to ride down with you?
answer: What for?

question: It's early.
answer: It must be one o'clock.

question: It's Saturday night! There's still plenty-a action around!
answer: Angie, by the time I get Clara home, it's gonna be one, one-thirty. By the time I get home, it's gonna be two o'clock. I gotta get up for ten o'clock mass tomorrow.

question: All right, I'll see you!
answer: Where you going? I'll see you tomorrow after mass! You got an elevator in this house?

question: Where you going? I'll see you tomorrow after mass! You got an elevator in this house?
answer: We just live one flight up.

question: So I'll call you tomorrow.
answer: Okay. Call me about two-thirty, because I won't be home from my aunt's till about then.

question: Okay, so I'll see you tomorrow night then.
answer: Okay.

question: Don't you think I feel lousy about this too?
answer: All right, Ginnie. I don't wanna talk anymore about it. I don't think I got one hour's sleep the whole night. Last night was the first time in my life I ever heard my mother cry, you know that?

question: Tommy...
answer: I don't wanna talk about it! I know what you're gonna say. A man's gotta stop being his mother's baby sooner or later. How many times you gonna say it? She's my mother, you know. I oughta have some feelings about her, don't you think?

question: Why do you always put me inna position of being the louse?
answer: Virginia, I don't wanna hear no more about it!

question: Tommy, I love you, and I know you feel lousy right now, but we're never gonna be happy unless we have a chance to work out our own lives. We can't keep talking in whispers like this the resta our lives. We gotta have some privacy. We...
answer: Can't you wait five minutes? I'll drive you over inna car. I just gotta put my shirt on, that's all. All right, get dressed, because we're gonna drive my mother over. Why couldn't you get along with her?! Why couldn't you make just a little effort?! She's a little hard to get along with! All right! All I asked you was try a little.

question: Tommy...
answer: I don't wanna hear anymore about it, you hear me? Hello, Aunt Theresa.

question: What about the time she wanted to make an old-fashioned Italian dinner for my brother, but you wouldn't let her!?
answer: Waddaya talking about?!!

question: Once a month you couldn't let her use the kitchen!
answer: I told her she could use the kitchen any time she wanted...

question: ...You hadda be the boss inna kitchen alla time!
answer: She don't wanna use my pots and pans!

question: Tommy, gimme a coupla minutes, because I promised Mr. Gazzara I'd let him know tomorrow. See, what I wanna know, Tom, if a buncha individual retail merchants get together, how does it operate? On individual mark- ups? You know what I mean? Say I'm the butcher and Aldo Capelli, he's the dairyman and grocer, so suppose I mark up thirty-five percent, but he works on forty, so...
answer: Waddaya talking about, do you know what you're talking about?

question: No, I don't know. That's why I'm asking you.
answer: Take the baby, will you?! Wadda you wanna buy a shop for, will you tell me? You gotta good job, you got no wife, you got no responsibilities. Boy, I wish I was you, boy. Waddaya wanna tie yourself down with a shop? What's he want? Five thousand down? You're gonna have to carry a mortgage sixty, seventy bucks a month. A mortgage anna note from the bank. For Pete's sake, you're a single man with no responsibilities. Stay that way, boy. Take my advice.

question: Well, you see, Thomas I figure the big problem is the supermarkets. But Patsy's shop, that's a specialized trade. The supermarkets don't carry Italian meat.
answer: Who buys Italian meat anymore? You think my wife buys Italian meat? She goes to the A&P, picks up some lamb chops wrapped in cellophane, opens up a canna peas, and that's dinner, boy.

question: Hey, I come home from your house last night, Marty was here with a girl.
answer: Who?

question: Marty.
answer: Your son Marty?

question: Well, what Marty you think is gonna be here in this house with a girl?
answer: Were the lights on?

question: Oh sure. This girl is a college graduate.
answer: They're the worst. College girls are one step from the streets. They smoke like men inna saloon. My son Joseph, his wife, you know, she types onna typewriter. One step from the streets, I tell you. Mrs. Pilletti ponders this philosophy for a moment.

question: That's the first time Marty ever brought a girl to this house. She seems like a nice girl. I think he has a feeling for this girl. You heard him sing. He been singing like that all morning.
answer: Well, that's all. You will see. Today, tomorrow, inna week, he's gonna say to you, "Hey, Ma, it's no good being a single man. I'm tired-a running around." Then he's gonna say, "Hey, Ma, wadda we need this old house? Why don't we sell this old house, move into a nicer parta town? A nice little apartment?"

question: I don't sell this house, I tell you that. This is my husband's house. I had six children in this house.
answer: You will see. A coupla months, you gonna be an old lady, sleeping onna couch in her daughter-in-law's house.

question: Catherine, you are a blanket of gloom. Wherever you are, the rain follows. Someday, you gonna smile, and we gonna declare a holiday.
answer: Hello, Ma, waddaya say, it's getting a little late.

question: Sure.
answer: Boy, this place is really coming to pieces. You know, Ma, I think we oughta sell this place. The whole joint's going to pieces. The plumbing is rusty. Everything. I'm gonna have to replaster the whole ceiling now. You know what we oughta do? We oughta get one of those new apartments they're building down on Southern Boulevard. A nicer parta town, you know?...You all set, Ma?

question: I'm all set. That was a nice girl last night, Marty. She wasn't a very good-looking girl, but she looks like a nice girl. I said, she wasn't a very good-looking girl... not very pretty...
answer: I heard you, Ma.

question: She looks a little old for you. About thirty-five, forty years old?
answer: She's twenty-nine, Ma.

question: She's more than twenty-nine years old, Marty. That's what she tells you.
answer: What, Ma?

question: She looks thirty-five, forty. She didn't look Italian to me. I said, is she Italian girl?
answer: I don't know. I don't think so.

question: She don't look Italian to me. What kinda family she come from? There was something about her I didn't like. It seems funny, the first time you meet her, she comes to your empty house alone. These college girls, they all one step fromma streets.
answer: What are you talking about? She's a nice girl.

question: She didn't look Italian to me. I don't like her.
answer: You don't like her. You only met her for two minutes.

question: Don't bring her to the house no more.
answer: What didn't you like about her?

question: I don't know! She don't look like Italian to me. Plenny a nice Italian girls around.
answer: Well, let's not get inna fight about it, Ma. What are you getting so worked up about? I just met the girl last night. I'm probably not gonna see her again. Hello, Lou, Angie come in yet?

question: Well, let's not get inna fight about it, Ma. What are you getting so worked up about? I just met the girl last night. I'm probably not gonna see her again. Hello, Lou, Angie come in yet?
answer: He was here last night till about two o'clock. I hear you really got stuck with a dog last night.

question: Who told you that?
answer: Angie. He says she was a real scrawny- looking thing.

question: Listen, somebody turn onna ballgame. It must be after one o'clock by now. Who you gonna call?
answer: I was gonna call that girl from last night. Take her to a movie tonight.

question: Are you kidding?
answer: Listen, Angie, I wanna tell you, you were very impolite last night. I introduced you to the girl, you just turned and walked off. Now, why did you do that?

question: You got me mad, that's why. Hey, Joe, show Marty that picture.
answer: Put that away, for Pete's sake. My mother's right out onna porch.

question: Put it away, Joe. My mother'll come walking in.
answer: Marty, let's go downna Seventy-Second Street area tonight.

question: I don't feel like going, Angie. I thought I'd take this girl to a movie.
answer: Boy, you really musta made out good last night.

question: We just talked.
answer: Boy, she musta been some talker. She musta been about fifty years old.

question: Let's go downa Seventy-Second Street.
answer: I told this dog I was gonna call her today about two-thirty.

question: Brush her. Listen, you wanna come with me tonight, or you wanna go with this dog?
answer: Waddaya getting so sore about?
